briefing.opening: Hello everyone. I will now begin the climate briefing for February 18, 2026.

sections.title: ğŸ”´ Deepening Climate Crisis: Warning for 3-Degree Warming and Widespread Impacts
sections.content: European climate scientists have advised the international community to prepare for a 3-degree global temperature increase, exceeding the Paris Agreement targets, and warned that economic damages from climate change have reached 77 trillion KRW annually over the past five years [1, 7, 35]. While climate change is accelerating, the pace of nature is slowing down [37], and widespread concerns are growing, with nearly half of Americans expecting to witness catastrophic impacts of climate change in their lifetime [40]. In particular, climate change has emerged as a global health issue [50], enabling tropical diseases like Chikungunya to spread across most parts of Europe [69], and coffee agriculture is facing an increase in extreme heat days [66].

sections.title: âš ï¸ Crisis in International Climate Governance: U.S. Policy Reversal and International Repercussions
sections.content: The United States has signaled significant repercussions for the international climate order by officially announcing the repeal of greenhouse gas regulations by former President Trump and indicating a potential withdrawal from the International Energy Agency (IEA), stating that 'carbon neutrality is not necessary' [4, 5, 8, 9, 10, 12, 13, 22]. The Trump administration claimed that climate change does not threaten public health and stripped the EPA of its climate change-related authorities, but the scientific community refutes these claims [43, 48]. This U.S. policy reversal is interpreted as a turning point for the Republican Party, which refers to climate change as a 'hoax' [47], and poses a serious challenge to the international community's collective response efforts.

sections.title: ğŸŒ± Expansion of Domestic and International Climate Action and Green Jobs
sections.content: Jobs related to climate change response are projected to increase by an average of 3.6% annually until 2032, adding a total of 118,000 positions, indicating that the climate crisis response industry is expected to be a significant driver for future job creation [2, 3, 6]. Domestically, community efforts to foster eco-friendly green generations are active, such as Yangcheon-gu's operation of the 'EGG Expedition' [11], and the Chuncheon Carbon Neutrality Support Center is highlighting the importance of local areas in achieving carbon neutrality by inviting proposals for policy support research projects [14, 20]. Companies are also participating in carbon neutrality efforts; S-OIL, for example, is accelerating its eco-friendly initiatives by accumulating 1.68 million carbon neutrality points through the issuance of electronic receipts [15, 17, 19, 23, 24]. Furthermore, positive progress is seen in the education sector, with a new law enacted in Illinois mandating climate change education for high school students [49].

sections.title: ğŸ‡°ğŸ‡· Expansion of Renewable Energy and Efforts to Build Sustainable Infrastructure
sections.content: Domestically, alongside the easing of regulations for renewable energy installation [25], on-site direct power transactions for renewable energy have begun at Daebul Industrial Complex, realizing a model that directly supplies power to businesses [26, 27, 31]. Jeollanam-do Province has secured all 2 trillion KRW worth of government bids for ESS (Energy Storage System), raising expectations for easing renewable energy output control [29]. Suwon City is also continuing community-level renewable energy transition efforts, such as promoting the 'Apartment RE100 Rooftop Solar Pilot Project' [32]. Shinhan Bank is contributing to building sustainable infrastructure through 'Productive Finance' cooperation with Hyundai Engineering & Construction, expanding financial support in data centers and new and renewable energy sectors [28, 33, 34]. Furthermore, Okcheon County is set to open the Daecheongho Lake waterway for the first time in 42 years and operate the eco-friendly electric boat 'Jeong Jiyong-ho,' which will serve as an excellent example of introducing eco-friendly transportation [36].

sections.title: ğŸŒ Diverse Impacts of Climate Change and Adaptation Efforts
sections.content: Climate change is having diverse impacts worldwide. A study showing that the impact range of extreme rainfall in Valencia, Spain, expanded by 55% due to climate change demonstrates the severity of climate disasters [39, 45]. The cement industry is facing challenges such as reduced shipments, carbon neutrality goals, and rising electricity costs [18], and a lake in Japan is showing warnings of gradual climate change [53]. Meanwhile, adaptation efforts in ecosystems are being reported, such as wolves observed consuming bones to cope with climate change [52, 54, 55, 56, 58, 59, 62, 64, 65, 67]. City-level preparations for change are also underway, with the Point Arena City Council considering revising its general plan in the wake of climate change [61].

briefing.closing: Today's briefing highlighted the severity of the climate crisis, alongside various domestic and international efforts and adaptation cases to overcome it. This is a critical time when strong international cooperation on climate change and concrete actions for a sustainable future are more urgently needed. This concludes the climate briefing for February 18, 2026.

articles.title: Despite '1.5-Degree Limit' Promise, European Climate Scientists Urge Preparation for '3-Degree Rise'
articles.original_title: â€˜1.5ë„ ì œí•œâ€™ ì•½ì†í–ˆëŠ”ë°Â·Â·Â·â€œì´ì   3ë„ ìƒìŠ¹ì— ëŒ€ë¹„í•´ì•¼â€ ìœ ëŸ½ ê¸°í›„ê³¼í•™ìë“¤ì˜ í˜¸ì†Œ
articles.description: The target set by the Paris Agreement is becoming increasingly difficult to achieve. Economic damages from climate change over the past five years have reached an annual 77 trillion won. On June 28 last year, a heatwave struck Rome, Italy, with a citizen seeking relief in a fountain (EPA Yonhap News). European climate scientists are urging the European Union (EU) to prepare for a global average temperature increase of 3 degrees Celsius or more, significantly surpassing the international community's target of 1.5 degrees above pre-industrial levels.

summary.phenomenon: European climate scientists have appealed to the European Union (EU) to prepare for a global average temperature increase of 3 degrees Celsius or more, exceeding the international community's target of 1.5 degrees above pre-industrial levels. Economic damages due to climate change over the past five years have amounted to 77 trillion won annually, and a heatwave occurred in Rome, Italy, on June 28 last year.
summary.cause: This is due to the fact that achieving the 1.5-degree limit target set by the Paris Agreement has become virtually impossible.
summary.outlook: European climate scientists anticipate that the European Union (EU) must prepare for a global average temperature increase of 3 degrees Celsius or more above pre-industrial levels.

articles.title: Daecheong Lake Waterway Reopens After 42 Years; Okcheon County to Operate Eco-friendly Electric Boat 'Jeong Jiyong-ho' Next Month
articles.original_title: ëŒ€ì²­í˜¸ ë±ƒê¸¸ 42ë…„ ë§Œì— ì—´ë¦°ë‹¤â€¦ì˜¥ì²œêµ°, ë‚´ë‹¬ ì¹œí™˜ê²½ ì „ê¸°ì„  â€˜ì •ì§€ìš©í˜¸â€™ ìš´í•­
articles.description: The 'Jeong Jiyong-ho' is scheduled to commence operations next month on Daecheong Lake in Okcheon, Chungcheongbuk-do (Image provided by Okcheon County). The Daecheong Lake waterway in Okcheon County, Chungcheongbuk-do, is reopening after 42 years. Okcheon County announced on the 18th that it will officially operate the eco-friendly electric ferry 'Jeong Jiyong-ho' starting next month, traversing a 21km section of Daecheong Lake from Janggye Pier in Annae-myeon to Dongnakjeong in Annam-myeon. This marks the first reopening of the Daecheong Lake waterway in 42 years, having been closed since the completion of the Daecheong Dam in 1980.

summary.phenomenon: The Daecheong Lake waterway in Okcheon County, Chungcheongbuk-do, is reopening after 42 years. Okcheon County will officially operate the eco-friendly electric ferry 'Jeong Jiyong-ho' starting next month on the 18th, covering a 21km section of Daecheong Lake connecting Janggye Pier in Annae-myeon to Dongnakjeong in Annam-myeon.
summary.cause: The waterway was closed immediately after the completion of Daecheong Dam in 1980 and is now reopening after 42 years.
summary.outlook: The eco-friendly electric boat 'Jeong Jiyong-ho' is scheduled to officially operate on the 21km section of Daecheong Lake starting next month.

summary.phenomenon: A study has revealed that chikungunya, a tropical disease, can now be transmitted by mosquitoes across most of Europe. Specifically, infections are possible for more than six months in Southern European countries like Spain and Greece, and for two months in Southeast England.
summary.cause: The rise in temperatures due to the climate crisis and the spread of invasive mosquitoes have enabled chikungunya infections.
summary.outlook: Continued global warming is projected to further increase the potential for this disease to spread.
